sections.text:
# Supplement to ## Invalid Proxies and Volatility Changes
Giovanni Angelini, Luca Fanelli, Luca Neri This version: February 2025

## INTRODUCTION

In this Supplement, we extend and complete the paper along several dimensions.
Section S. 1 introduces some notation and special matrices utilized in the paper. Section S. 2 complements Proposition 1 with the discussion of a corollary which clarifies that the only possible scenario where the dynamic causal effects can be estimated consistently ignoring volatility shifts is when relative (normalized) responses are estimated and IRFs remain constant across volatility regimes (up to scale). Section S. 3 discusses a specific, illustrative example of a proxy-SVAR with a volatility break specified under stability restrictions.

Section S. 4 extends the identification and estimation approach discussed in the paper along two dimensions. Firstly, it considers the case where the number of volatility breaks is $M \geq 2$, resulting in $M+1$ volatilty regimes. Secondly, it explores QML estimation as an alternative to the CMD estimation discussed in the paper.

Section S. 5 complements the Monte Carlo results presented in the paper providing details on the design of the experiments and focusing on methods to indirectly assess, expost, the identifiability of the proxy-SVAR when the information from volatility shifts is limited.

Section S. 6 supplements the empirical analysis presented in the paper with further details and additional results. It clarifies how fiscal multipliers are computed in our framework, explains the specification of the proxy-SVAR estimated on the whole sample without accounting for the volatility shift, and provides a detailed discussion of the estimated fiscal spending multipliers which were not extensively analyzed in the main text due to space constraints.

Section S. 7 summarizes proofs of propositions and corollaries presented in the paper.
Unless differently specified, hereafter all references - except those starting with 'S.' refer to sections, assumptions, equations and results in the main paper.

## S. 1 SPECIAL MATRICES

In the paper and in what follows, we make use of the following matrices (Magnus and Neudecker, 1999): $D_{n}$ is the $n$-dimensional duplication matrix $\left(D_{n} v e c h(A)=v e c(A), A\right.$ being an $n \times n$ matrix) and $D_{n}^{+}:=\left(D_{n}^{\prime} D_{n}\right)^{-1} D_{n}$ is the Moore-Penrose generalized inverse of $D_{n} . K_{n s}$ is the $n s$-dimensional commutation matrix $\left(K_{n s} v e c(A)=v e c\left(A^{\prime}\right), A\right.$ being $n \times s)$. We simply use $K_{n}$ in place of $K_{n n}$ when $n=s$. In the proof of propositions we often exploit the result: $D_{n}^{+} N_{n}=D_{n}^{+}$, where $N_{n}:=\frac{1}{2}\left(I_{n^{2}}+K_{n}\right)$.

Furthermore, we denote with $\operatorname{vecd}(A)$ the vector containing the diagonal elements of the square matrix $A$. Then, given the $p \times p$ diagonal matrix $A \equiv d g(A)$, the $p^{2} \times p$ derivative $\mathcal{F}_{A}:=\frac{\partial v e c(A)}{\partial \operatorname{vecd}(A)^{\prime}}$ contains by construction ' 0 ' and ' 1 '. Specifically, the matrix $\mathcal{F}_{A}$ is such that

$\operatorname{rank}\left[\mathcal{F}_{A}\right]=p$ if the diagonal elements of $A$ are distinct. Conversely, $\operatorname{rank}\left[\mathcal{F}_{A}\right]=p-p_{1}$ when there are $p_{1}$ repeated elements on the diagonal of $A$.

# S. 2 MORE ON THE ESTIMATION OF TARGET IRF's IGNORING VOLATILITY SHIFTS 

In this section, we complement the results in Section 2.3. In particular, the following corollary specializes the result in Proposition 1 to the scenario where the volatility shift is not caused by changes in the on-impact coefficients $\left(\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}=0_{n \times k}\right)$. This scenario represents a common assumption in the classical identification-through-heteroskedasticity approach, where the change in volatility is ascribed solely to variations in the variances of the structural shocks.

Corollary 1 (Probability limit of $\hat{\Sigma}_{u, z}$ with $\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}^{(0)}=0_{n \times k}$ ) Under the same conditions as Proposition 1, with $\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}^{(0)}=0_{n \times k}$ in (12):
(i) $\hat{\Sigma}_{u, z} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}\left[\tau_{B}^{(0)} H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}+\left(1-\tau_{B}^{(0)}\right) H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\left(\Lambda_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\right)^{1 / 2}\right]\left(\Phi^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}$;
(ii) for $k=1, \quad \hat{\Sigma}_{u_{2}, z} / \hat{\Sigma}_{u_{1}, z}^{-1} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{E}} H_{2,1}^{\text {rel. }(0)}$.

According to Corollary 1, the covariance matrix estimator $\hat{\Sigma}_{u, z}$ can be used to consistently estimate the target IRFs on the entire estimation sample only when two specific conditions are met: (i) responses remain constant across the two volatility regimes; (ii) the analysis focuses on relative responses obtained by imposing unit effect normalizations (see, e.g., Stock and Watson, 2018) rather than absolute responses.

Interestingly, Corollary 1.(ii) provides a theoretical rationale for some of the findings reported in Schlaak, Rieth, and Podstawski (2023), primarily obtained through simulation studies. Corollary 1 highlights that incorporating the moment conditions implied by a shift in volatility into a framework where consistent estimation of the target IRFs is already achievable, can only enhance estimation precision (see also Carriero, Marcellino, and Tornese, 2024). This insight underscores the potential benefits of leveraging information from volatility shifts, even when consistent estimation is possible without it.

## S. 3 Stability RESTRICTIONS: AN EXTENSIVE EXAMPLE

This section presents an example that clarifies the notation used in the paper for stability restrictions and illustrates the richness and flexibility of the suggested approach, defined by the moment conditions (16) under the restrictions (18).

Example 1 Consider the proxy-SVAR under Assumptions 1-2, with $n=3$ variables in $Y_{t}$ and one instrument for one target shock $\varepsilon_{1, t}, r=k=1$. In this framework, $\Phi=\varphi$ and $\Omega_{t r}=\omega$ are scalars. The system features $n-k=2$ non-target shocks $\varepsilon_{2, t}:=\left(\epsilon_{2, t}, \epsilon_{3, t}\right)^{\prime}$, hence $\Upsilon=\left(v_{1}, v_{2}\right)$ is $1 \times 2$, with $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$ being contamination parameters. Assume that

under a set of stability restrictions as in (18), the matrices $G, G+\Delta_{G}$ and $\Psi$ are given by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& G:=\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
h_{11} & h_{12} & h_{13} & \\
h_{21} & h_{22} & h_{23} & \\
h_{31} & h_{32} & h_{33} & \\
\varphi & v_{1} & v_{2} & \omega
\end{array}\right)}_{\text {vol. regime1 }}, G+\Delta_{G}:=\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
h_{11}+\Delta_{h_{11}} & h_{12} & h_{13} & \\
h_{21}+\Delta_{h_{21}} & h_{22} & h_{23} & \\
h_{31}+\Delta_{h_{31}} & h_{32} & h_{33} & \\
\varphi+\Delta_{\varphi} & v_{1} & v_{2} & \omega
\end{array}\right)}_{\text {vol. regime2 }} \\
& \Psi:=\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{llll}
1 & & & \\
& \psi_{2} & & \\
& & \psi_{3} & \\
& & & \psi_{4}
\end{array}\right)}_{\text {change of relative variances in } \xi_{t}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where blank areas in $G$ and $G+\Delta_{G}$ correspond to the no impact of instrument measurement error on the variables, for $i=1,2,3, h_{i j}$ denotes the $(i, j)$ element of $H, \Delta h_{i j}$ and $\Delta \varphi$ are the parameters assumed to change in the shift across the two volatility regimes. In this setup, the order condition in Proposition 2.(ii) allows instrument contamination, leaving $v_{1}$ and $v_{2}$ unrestricted. Finally, the parameters $\psi_{2}, \psi_{3}$ and $\psi_{4}$ on the main diagonal of $\Psi$ capture the relative shifts in variance of the shocks in $\varepsilon_{2, t}$ and measurement error $\zeta_{t}$, when moving to the second regime. The restrictions on $\Psi$ are obtained by specifying $S_{\Psi}$ and $s_{\Psi}$ in (18) as follows:

$$
\operatorname{vecd}(\Psi)=\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & 0 & 0 \\
1 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & 1 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{array}\right)}_{\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
S_{\Psi}
\end{array}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\psi_{2} \\
\psi_{3} \\
\psi_{4}
\end{array}\right)+\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
0 \\
0 \\
0
\end{array}\right)}_{\begin{array}{c}
0 \\
s_{\Psi}
\end{array}}
$$

so that $c=\operatorname{dim}(\psi)=3$. The restrictions on $G$ are obtained similarly but the matrices $S_{G}$ and $s_{G}$ in (18) are of large dimensions and therefore omitted for space. The restrictions on $\Delta_{G}$ are obtained by specifying $S_{\Delta_{G}}$ and $s_{\Delta_{G}}$ in (18) as follows:

$$
\operatorname{vec}\left(\Delta_{G}\right)=S_{\Delta_{G}} \underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{c}
\Delta_{h_{11}} \\
\Delta_{h_{21}} \\
\Delta_{h_{31}} \\
\Delta_{\varphi} \\
\delta
\end{array}\right)}_{\delta}
$$

with $S_{\Delta_{G}} 16 \times 4$ selection matrix having one in the first 4 rows and zeros elsewhere and $s_{\Delta_{G}}=0_{16 \times 1}$.

Example 1 defines a proxy-SVAR model which is just-identified according to the necessary and sufficient rank condition presented in Proposition 2. In particular, in this specification there are $a+b+c=20$ nonzero, unrestricted parameters in the matrices $G$ $(\gamma), \Delta_{G}(\delta)$ and $\Psi(\psi)$, which can be uniquely recovered from the $(n+r)(n+r+1)=20$ reduced-form equations in the reduced-form covariance matrices $\Sigma_{\eta, 1}$ and $\Sigma_{\eta, 2}$, respectively. An additional restriction on $\gamma$ (e.g. $v_{2}=0$ (implying that $z_{t}$ is orthogonal to the non-target shock $\epsilon_{3, t}$ ), or on $\delta$ (e.g. $\Delta_{\varphi}=0$, implying that instrument relevance does not change across

the two volatility regimes) are overidentifying, therefore testable.
The volatility shift is here explained by the change in the impact of the target shock on the variables, through the coefficients $\Delta_{h_{11}}, \Delta_{h_{21}}$ and $\Delta_{h_{31}}$ on the one hand, and the change in the variances of the non-target shocks and instrument measurement error, reflected in the elements of the vector $\psi$, on the other hand.

Interestingly, provided $\Delta_{\varphi} \neq 0$, also the change in the instrument relevance contributes to the change in volatility. The value ' 1 ' in the $(1,1)$ position of the matrix $\Psi$ implies, in this example, that the variance of the target shock remains unchanged across volatility regimes, so that only the change in the impact of the target shock on the variables contributes to the shift in volatility. For normalized IRFs, misspecification in the relative change of variance in $\varepsilon_{1, t}$ is not consequential. In fact, the IRFs are in that case identified up to scale. Furthermore, provided $\Upsilon:=\left(v_{1}, v_{2}\right) \neq(0,0)$ (i.e., the instrument is contaminated by the two non-target shocks), the variance of the external instrument is equal to $\varphi^{2}+\Upsilon \Upsilon^{\prime}+\omega^{2}$ in the first volatility regime and becomes $\left(\varphi+\Delta_{\varphi}\right)^{2}+\Upsilon \Upsilon^{\prime}+\omega^{2}$ in the second volatility regime, implying a shift in the correlation between the instrument and both the target and non-target shocks.

Aside from the VAR dynamics, the parameters necessary to estimate the target IRFs (13) in Example 1 are collected in the vector $\theta:=\left(h_{11}, h_{21}, h_{31}, \Delta h_{11}, \Delta h_{21}, \Delta h_{31}\right)^{\prime}$. However, all other nuisance parameters are identified and can be estimated consistently along with $\theta$. Note, in particular, that Example 1 depicts a scenario where, despite the model features two non-target shocks $(n-k)=2$, no restriction is needed on $H_{\bullet 2}$ to achieve identification. Furthermore, stability restrictions here posit that the impact of the non-target shock on the variable is constant across the two volatility regimes. Specifically, equation (S.2) maintains that, provided the parameters $\psi_{2}$ and $\psi_{3}$ are significantly different from 1 , the non-target shocks contribute to the shift in volatility solely through changes in their relative variances, a quite neutral hypothesis for nuisance objects. This is in line with the partial identification logic characterizing proxy-SVARs. However, as is demonstrated in the empirical illustration presented in the paper, the stability restrictions in (18) are flexible enough to allow the specification of identifying constraints on both $H_{\bullet 2}$ and $\Delta_{H_{\bullet 2}}$ when the investigator can leverage credible, uncontroversial restrictions pertaining the impact of the the non-target shocks on the variables.

# S. 4 MULTIPLE VOLATILITY REGIMES AND QML ESTIMATION 

This section extends the identification and estimation approach discussed in the paper along two dimensions: first, considering the case where the are at least two changes in volatility $(M \geq 2)$ resulting in $M+1$ volatility regimes (Section S.4.1), and second, QML estimation of the proxy-SVAR under stability restrictions (Section S.4.2).

## S.4.1 MULTIPLE VOLATILITY REGIMES

The reduced-form proxy-SVAR model is the same as in equation (11), but now the parameters are allowed to change at the break points $T_{B_{1}}, \ldots, T_{B_{M}}$, where $1<T_{B_{1}}, \ldots,<T_{B_{M}}<T$.

Conventionally we assume that $T_{B_{0}}:=1$ and $T_{B_{M+1}}:=T$. The assumption that follows generalizes Assumptions 1-2 in the paper to a broader framework.

Assumption 3 Given the proxy-SVAR (11),
(i) the are $M$ known break points, $1<T_{B_{1}}<\ldots<T_{B_{M}}<T$, such that $T_{B_{1}} \geq(n+r)$, $T_{B_{i}}-T_{B_{i-1}} \geq(n+r), i=2, \ldots, M+1,(n+r):=\operatorname{dim}\left(W_{t}\right)$;
(ii) the law of motion of the autoregressive (slope) parameters $\pi(t):=\operatorname{vec}(\Gamma(t))$ and the unconditional covariance matrix $\sigma_{\eta}(t):=\operatorname{vech}\left(\Sigma_{\eta}(t)\right)$ are given by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi(t) & =\sum_{i=1}^{M+1} \pi_{i} \times \mathbb{I}\left(T_{B_{i-1}}+1 \leq t \leq T_{B_{i}}\right), t=1, \ldots, T \\
\sigma_{\eta}(t) & =\sum_{i=1}^{M+1} \sigma_{\eta, i} \times \mathbb{I}\left(T_{B_{i-1}}+1 \leq t \leq T_{B_{i}}\right), t=1, \ldots, T
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Sigma_{\eta, i}<\infty, i=1, \ldots, M+1$ and:

$$
\sigma_{\eta, i}:=\operatorname{vech}\left(\Sigma_{\eta, i}\right) \neq \sigma_{\eta, j}:=\operatorname{vech}\left(\Sigma_{\eta, j}\right) \quad \text { for } i \neq j
$$

(iii) the process $\left\{\eta_{t}\right\}$, where $\eta_{t}:=\left(u_{t}^{\prime}, z_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}$, is $\alpha$-mixing and has absolutely summable cumulants up to order eight on the $M+1$ volatility regimes.

The relationships between the VAR disturbances and proxies and the structural shocks and measurement errors is given by $u_{t}=G(t) \xi_{t}$, where $\xi_{t}$ is normalized to have unit variance across the $M+1$ volatility regimes (hence matrices $\Psi_{i}$ are set to the identity for $i=2, \ldots, M+1)$, and $G(t)$ is defined by:

$$
G(t):=G+\sum_{i=2}^{M+1} \Delta_{G_{i}} \times \mathbb{I}\left(T_{B_{i-1}}+1 \leq t \leq T_{B_{i}}\right), t=1, \ldots, T
$$

In (S.4), $\Delta_{G_{i}}:=G^{(i)}-G^{(i-1)}, i=2, \ldots, M+1\left(G^{(1)}:=G\right)$ are $(n+r) \times(n+r)$ matrices. In (S.4), $G$ contains the nonzero structural parameters before any break occurs, while the nonzero elements in the matrices $\Delta_{G_{i}} i=2, \ldots, M+1$ describe how and to what extent the instantaneous impact of the structural shocks changes across volatility regimes.

The mapping between the reduced- and structural-form parameters is now given by:

$$
\Sigma_{\eta, 1}=G G^{\prime} \quad, \quad \Sigma_{\eta, i}=\left(G+\sum_{j=2}^{i} \Delta_{G_{j}}\right)\left(G+\sum_{j=2}^{i} \Delta_{G_{j}}\right)^{\prime}, \quad i=2, \ldots, M+1
$$

and the linear identifying restrictions characterizing $G$ and $\Delta_{G_{i}}, i=2, \ldots, M+1$, can be

collected in the expression:

$$
\left(\begin{array}{c}
\operatorname{vec}(G) \\
\operatorname{vec}\left(\Delta_{G_{2}}\right) \\
\vdots \\
\operatorname{vec}\left(\Delta_{G_{M+1}}\right)
\end{array}\right)=\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
S_{G} & & \cdots & \\
& S_{\Delta_{G_{2}}} & \cdots & \\
& & \ddots & \vdots \\
& & & S_{\Delta_{G_{M+1}}}
\end{array}\right)}_{S^{*}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\gamma \\
\delta_{2} \\
\vdots \\
\delta_{M+1}
\end{array}\right)
$$

In (S.6), $\gamma$ is the $a \times 1$ vector $(a=\operatorname{dim}(\gamma))$ that collects the free (unrestricted) elements in the matrix $G$, and $\delta_{i}$ is the $b_{i} \times 1$ vector $\left(b_{i}=\operatorname{dim}\left(\delta_{i}\right)\right)$ containing the free elements in the matrices $\Delta_{G_{i}}, i=2, \ldots, M+1$. The selection matrices $S_{G}, s_{G}, S_{\Delta_{G_{2}}}$ and $s_{\Delta_{G_{2}}}$ are of conformable dimensions and have obvious interpretation. To simplify notation, the "big" selection matrix in system (S.6) is summarized in the $(M+1)(n+r) \times\left(a+b_{2}+\ldots+b_{M+1}\right)$ matrix $S^{*}$.

Given the proxy-SVAR in Assumptions 1-2, consider the moment conditions in (19) where $G, \Delta_{G}$ and $\Psi$ are restricted as in (18). Assume $\varsigma_{0} \in \mathcal{P}_{\varsigma}$ is a regular point of $\mathcal{J}(\varsigma):=\partial m\left(\sigma_{\eta}, \varsigma\right) / \partial \varsigma^{\prime}$.

Proposition S. 1 (Identification under changing IRFs, $M+1$ REGIMEs) Given the proxy-SVAR in Assumptions 2-3, consider the moment conditions in (19) where $G, \Delta_{G_{i}}$ for $i=2, \ldots, M+1$ are restricted as in (S.6) and set $\Psi=I_{n+r}$. Consider $\varsigma:=\left(\gamma^{\prime}, \delta_{2}^{\prime}, \ldots, \delta_{M+1}^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}$. Assume $\varsigma_{0} \in \mathcal{P}_{\varsigma}$ is a regular point of $\mathcal{J}(\varsigma):=\partial m\left(\sigma_{\eta}, \varsigma\right) / \partial \varsigma^{\prime}$. Then, irrespective of proxy properties:
(i) a necessary and sufficient condition for the (local) identification of $\varsigma_{0}$ is that $\operatorname{rank}[\mathcal{J}(\varsigma)]=$ $a+b_{2}+\ldots+b_{M+1}$ in a neighborhood of $\varsigma_{0}$, where $\mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma_{0}\right)$ is the $(1 / 2)(M+1)(n+r)(n+r+$ 1) $\times\left(a+b_{2}+\ldots+b_{M+1}\right)$ Jacobian evaluated at $\varsigma_{0}, \mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma_{0}\right):=\mathcal{J}(\varsigma)_{\varsigma=\varsigma_{0}}$, with

$$
\mathcal{J}(\varsigma)=2\left(I_{M+1} \otimes D_{n+r}^{+}\right) \mathcal{H}_{M+1}(\varsigma) S^{*}
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{H}_{M+1}(\varsigma)=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
\left(G \otimes I_{n+r}\right) & & & \\
\left(G+\Delta_{G_{2}}\right) \otimes I_{n+r} & \left(G+\Delta_{G_{2}}\right) \otimes I_{n+r} & & \\
\vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \\
\left(G+\Delta_{G_{M+1}}\right) \otimes I_{n+r} & \left(G+\Delta_{G_{M+1}}\right) \otimes I_{n+r} & \cdots & \left(G+\Delta_{G_{M+1}}\right) \otimes I_{n+r}
\end{array}\right)
$$

(ii) A necessary order condition is:

$$
\left(a+b_{2}+\ldots+b_{M+1}\right) \leq(M+1)(n+r)(n+r+1) / 2
$$

Note that for $M=1$, Proposition S. 1 collapses to Proposition 2 in the paper. Proposition S. 1 can be extended to unrestricted (multiple) $\Psi$ with appropriate adjustments to $\varsigma$, $S^{*}$, and $\mathcal{H}_{M+1}(\varsigma)$.

When the necessary and sufficient rank condition in Proposition S. 1 is satisfied, the proxy-SVAR can be estimated by extending the CMD approach discussed in the paper to the multiple volatility regimes case.

# S.4.2 QML ESTIMATION 

To simplify exposition, in the remainder of this section we consider quasi-maximum likelihood estimation based on observations:

$$
W_{-l+1}, W_{-l+2}, \ldots, W_{0}, W_{1}, \ldots, W_{T}
$$

for the case of a single break $(M=1)$ occurring at the known date $t=T_{B}$, i.e. two volatility regimes in the data. The generalization to the case $M \geq 2$ is tedious but straightforward. Hence, given the reduced-form model (11), the QML estimation for the whole sample, $W_{1}, \ldots, W_{T}$, conditional on $W_{-l+1}, W_{-l+2} \ldots, W_{0}$, based on the assumption of conditionally Gaussian errors, is given by:

$$
\prod_{i=1}^{M+1} \prod_{t=T_{B_{i-1}}+1}^{T_{B_{i}}} f\left(W_{t} \mid W_{t-1}, \ldots, W_{t-l} ; \Gamma_{i}, \Sigma_{\eta, i}\right)
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
f\left(W_{t}\right. & \left.\left|W_{t-1}, \ldots, W_{t-l}\right; \Gamma_{i}, \Sigma_{\eta, i}\right) \\
& =\frac{1}{\left(2 \pi \operatorname{det}\left(\Sigma_{\eta, i}\right)\right)^{1 / 2}} \exp \left\{-\frac{1}{2}\left[W_{t}-\Gamma_{i} X_{t}\right]^{\prime} \Sigma_{\eta, i}^{-1}\left[W_{t}-\Gamma_{i} X_{t}\right]\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

By standard manipulations, and conventionally denoting with $\hat{G}=G(\gamma)$ and $\hat{\Delta}_{G}=\Delta_{G}(\delta)$ the counterparts of the matrices $G$ and $\Delta_{G}$ that satisfy the identification conditions in Proposition 2, the concentrated, quasi-Gaussian log-likelihood of the proxy-SVAR reduces to:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\log L_{T}(\varsigma)= & \text { const }-\frac{T_{B}}{2} \log |\hat{G}|^{2}-\frac{T-T_{B}+1}{2} \log \left|\hat{G}+\hat{\Delta}_{G}\right|^{2} \\
& -\frac{T_{B}}{2} t r\left(\hat{G}^{-1}\left(\hat{G}^{-1}\right)^{\prime} \hat{\Sigma}_{\eta, 1}\right) \\
& -\frac{T-T_{B}+1}{2} t r\left(\left(\left(\hat{G}+\hat{\Delta}_{G}\right)^{-1}\right)^{\prime}\left(\hat{G}+\hat{\Delta}_{G}\right)^{-1} \hat{\Sigma}_{\eta, 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\Sigma}_{\eta, 1}$ and $\hat{\Sigma}_{\eta, 2}$ are estimates of the reduced-form covariance matrices obtained from the two volatility regimes. Bacchiocchi and Fanelli (2015) discuss the derivation of the score and associated information matrix for a case analogous to the quasi-likelihood function in (S.8).

## S. 5 FURTHER MONTE CARLO RESULTS AND LIMITED INFORMATION FROM VOLATILITY SHIFTS

This section provides further details about the Monte Carlo experiments presented in the paper and introduces additional results. Specifically, we discuss the design of the experiments, the measure of relative performance used for comparisons with other methods, and

finally, we investigate whether the estimation of the smallest singular value of the Jacobian matrix $\mathcal{J}(\varsigma)$ (see Proposition 2) is useful for detecting, ex-post, situations where shifts in volatility provide limited information for identification.

DESIGN OF THE EXPERIMENT The design of the experiment is as follows. We generate pseudo-samples of length $T$ from a bivariate $(n=2)$ stable VAR(1) with zero initial values $\left(Y_{0}:=0_{2 \times 1}\right)$, and a single break in the unconditional covariance matrix occurring at the break date $T_{B}:=\lfloor 0.5 T\rfloor$, i.e. located at the middle of the overall sample. The DGP matrix of autoregressive parameters (see (8)) is given by:

$$
\Pi:=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0.8250 & 0.5000 \\
-0.2000 & 0.75
\end{array}\right)
$$

and its largest eigenvalue in modulus is equal to 0.84 , a persistence that aligns with the level we observe in empirical analyses. Given the vector of structural shocks, $\varepsilon_{t}:=\left(\varepsilon_{1, t}, \varepsilon_{2, t}\right)^{\prime}$, $\varepsilon_{1, t}$ is the target structural shock ( $\varepsilon_{2, t}$ the non-target shock), which is instrumented by the proxy $z_{t}(r=k=1)$. The DGP for the instrument $z_{t}$ is described by the linear measurement error model:

$$
\begin{aligned}
z_{t}=\left[\varphi+\Delta_{\varphi} \cdot \mathbb{I}\left(t \geq\right.\right. & \left.T_{B}+1\right)] \varepsilon_{1, t}+\left[v+\Delta_{v} \cdot \mathbb{I}\left(t \geq T_{B}+1\right)\right] \varepsilon_{2, t} \\
& \left.+\left[\omega+\Delta_{\omega} \cdot \mathbb{I}\left(t \geq T_{B}+1\right)\right] \zeta_{t}, \quad t=1, \ldots, T\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\varphi$ and $\varphi+\Delta_{\varphi}$ are the relevance parameters, $v, v+\Delta_{v}$ the contamination parameters, whose nonzero values capture the connections of the instrument with the non-target shock. Finally, $\omega$ is the standard deviation of the proxy's measurement error $\zeta_{t}$. In this design, also the variance of the measurement error may changes from $\omega^{2}$ to $\left(\omega+\Delta_{\omega}\right)^{2}$ in the shift from the first to the second volatility regime. Relevance and exogeneity/contamination are captured by the correlations:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{corr}\left(z_{t}, \varepsilon_{1, t}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{\varphi}{\left(\varphi^{2}+v^{2}+\omega^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}, & t \leq T_{B} \\
\frac{\varphi+\Delta_{\varphi}}{\left(\left(\varphi+\Delta_{\varphi}\right)^{2}+\left(v+\Delta_{v}\right)^{2}+\left(\omega+\Delta_{\omega}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}, & t \geq T_{B}+1
\end{array}\right. \\
& \operatorname{corr}\left(z_{t}, \varepsilon_{2, t}\right)=\left\{\begin{array}{lc}
\frac{v}{\left(\varphi^{2}+v^{2}+\omega^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}, & t \leq T_{B} \\
\frac{v+\Delta_{v}}{\left(\left(\varphi+\Delta_{\varphi}\right)^{2}+\left(v+\Delta_{v}\right)^{2}+\left(\omega+\Delta_{\omega}\right)^{2}\right)^{1 / 2}}, & t \geq T_{B}+1
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

We consider scenarios in which the external instrument satisfies the exogeneity condition $\left(\Upsilon=0, v+\Delta_{v}=0\right.$, implying $\operatorname{corr}\left(z_{t}, \varepsilon_{2, t}\right)=0$ for any $\left.t\right)$, and scenarios where it does not $\left(v \neq 0, v+\Delta_{v} \neq 0\right)$. Similarly, we examine situations in which relevance is met, meaning that the correlation with the target shock is strong on the estimation sample, and scenarios in which the external instrument is local-to-zero as in Staiger and Stock (1997), i.e. $\varphi:=c T^{-1 / 2}$, with $|c|<\infty$. In general, the design covers all possible instrument properties, see c.(i)-c.(iv), Section 2. The DGP values for $\varphi, v, \omega$ and $\Delta_{\omega}$ are specified below.

By combining the VAR with the external instrument for $\varepsilon_{1, t}$, the covariance matrices satisfy, under Assumption 1, the moment conditions:

$$
\Sigma_{\eta, 1}=G G^{\prime}
$$

$$
\Sigma_{\eta, 2}=\left(G+\Delta_{G}\right) \Psi\left(G+\Delta_{G}\right)^{\prime}
$$

with DGP values for $G, \Delta_{G}$ and $\Psi$ given by:

$$
\begin{aligned}
G & =\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
H_{\bullet 1} & H_{\bullet 2} & 0_{2 \times 1} \\
\Phi & \Upsilon & \Omega_{t r}
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
1.00 & 0.40 & 0 \\
0.70 & 0.90 & 0 \\
\varphi & v & 1
\end{array}\right) \\
\Delta_{G} & =\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}} & \Delta_{H_{\bullet 2}} & 0_{2 \times 1} \\
\Delta_{\Phi} & \Delta_{\Upsilon} & \Delta_{\Omega_{t r}}
\end{array}\right):=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
-0.50 & 0 & 0 \\
-1.00 & 0 & 0 \\
\Delta_{\varphi} & \Delta_{v} & -0.04
\end{array}\right) \\
\Psi & =I_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The true vector of structural parameters is $\varsigma^{(0)}:=\left(\gamma_{0}^{\prime}, \delta_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}$, with

$$
\gamma_{0}:=\left(1,0.7,0.40,0.90, \varphi_{0}, v_{0}, 1\right)^{\prime} \quad \text { and } \quad \delta_{0}:=\left(-0.5,-1, \Delta_{\varphi, 0}, \Delta_{v, 0},-0.040\right)^{\prime}
$$

In this design, the target IRFs in (13) change across the two volatility regimes solely because of changes in the on-impact parameters $H_{\bullet 1}:=(1,0.7)^{\prime}$, as captured by the elements in $\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}:=\left(-0.5,-1\right)^{\prime}$. Overall, the total number of structural parameters to estimate when $v \neq 0, \Delta_{v} \neq 0$ (instrument exogeneity fails) is 11 , while there are $(n+r)(n+r+1)=12$ moment conditions. Therefore, the proxy-SVAR incorporates one $(d=1)$ testable overidentifying restriction when $v \neq 0, \Delta_{v} \neq 0$ (exogeneity fails), and three $(d=3)$ testable overidentifying restrictions when $v=0, \Delta_{v}=0$ (instrument exogeneity holds) and the zero restrictions are imposed in estimation. The necessary and sufficient rank condition implied by Proposition 2 is satisfied for the specified values of $\left(\varphi_{0}, \Delta_{\varphi, 0}\right)$ and $\left(v_{0}, \Delta_{v, 0}\right)$ we consider below.

In all experiments, we generate $N=10,000$ samples of lengths $T=\{250,500,1,000\}$, respectively, under the hypothesis that the structural shocks $\varepsilon_{t}:=\left(\varepsilon_{1, t}, \varepsilon_{2, t}\right)^{\prime}$ and the proxy's measurement error $\zeta_{t}$ are drawn from iid $N(0,1)$ processes. ${ }^{1}$ When dealing with strong proxies, the DGP values of $\varphi$ and $\Delta_{\varphi}$ are such that $\operatorname{corr}\left(\varepsilon_{1, t}, z_{t}\right)=0.58$ for the full sample. Instead, when dealing with + local-to-zero proxies, the correlations vary with the sample size, namely $\operatorname{corr}\left(\varepsilon_{1, t}, z_{t}\right)=\{0.045,0.0318,0.0225\}$, depending on whether the sample length $T$ is equal to 250,500 or 1,000 respectively.

Measure of Relative Performance Table 2 summarizes measures of relative performance. These are based on Mean Squared Error (MSE) and are inspired by Schlaak et al. (2023). We explain how these measures are constructed.

For $\mathrm{q} \geq 2$, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{rel}-\operatorname{MSE} E_{\text {Model. } 1}^{\text {Model. } 1}: & =\tau_{B} \times \operatorname{rel}-\operatorname{MSE} E_{\text {Model. } 1}^{\text {Model. } 1}(t) \mathbb{I}\left(t \leq T_{B}\right) \\
& +\left(1-\tau_{B}\right) \times \operatorname{rel}-\operatorname{MSE} E_{\text {Model. } 1}^{\text {Model. } 1}(t) \mathbb{I}\left(t>T_{B}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ We can relax both Gaussianity and the iid hypothesis provided the process $\eta_{t}:=\left(u_{t}^{\prime}, z_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}$ respects the $\alpha$-mixing conditions stated in Assumption 1.

where $\tau_{B}:=\left\lfloor T_{B} / T\right\rfloor$ is the fraction of the sample covering the first volatility regime and:

$$
\operatorname{rel}-\operatorname{MSE}_{M o d e l .1}^{\text {Model.q }}(t):=\frac{1}{25} \sum_{h=0}^{25-1}\left\{\frac{\frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\widehat{I R F}_{i, 1, j}^{\text {Model.q }}(t, h)-\operatorname{IRF}_{i, 1}^{0}(t, h)\right)^{2}}{\frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(\widehat{I R F}_{i, 1, j}^{\text {Model.1 }}(t, h)-\operatorname{IRF}_{i, 1}^{0}(t, h)\right)^{2}}\right\}
$$

In (S.9)-(S.10), $N=10,000$ is the number of Monte Carlo simulations (with $j$ associated index), $i=\{1,2\}$ denotes the response variable in $Y_{t}=\left(Y_{1, t}, Y_{2, t}\right)^{\prime}, I R F_{i, 1}^{0}(t, h)$ is the true value of the absolute response of $Y_{i, t+h}$ to the target shock $\varepsilon_{1, t}$ (see equation (13)), and $\widehat{I R F}_{i, 1, j}^{\text {Model.q }}(t, h)$ the corresponding estimate obtained from Model.q on the sample of observation generated at the $j$-th DGP. The measures in (S.9)-(S.10) are opportunely adapted to considering the whole sample of length $T$ for Model. 4 and Model.5, where the target IRFs are kept constant across the two volatility regimes.

For $q \geq 2$, measures obtained from (S.9)-(S.10) greater than 1 indicate that Model. $q$ performs worse in terms of MSE than the benchmark Model.1. Conversely, values less than 1 indicate that there are relative gains in performance.

# CHECKs OF IDENTIFIABILITY AND LIMITED INFORMATION FROM VOLATILITY SHIFTS 

The results in Table 1 and Table 2 are obtained under scenarios in which the proxySVAR with a break in unconditional volatility is identified. Identifiability depends on the full column rank condition of the Jacobian matrix $\mathcal{J}(\varsigma)$, as derived in Proposition 2; see equation (20).

In practical situations, investigators can, in principle, test the rank of the Jacobian matrix ex-post, meaning after estimating the model and substituting the elements in $G$, $\Delta_{G}$ and $\Psi$ in (20) with their estimates, obtaining $\mathcal{J}\left(\zeta_{T}\right)$. Tests of rank that can be applied in these cases are discussed in e.g. Al-Sadoon (2017); see also references therein.

In the empirical illustration discussed in Section 3, we assessed the quality of identification by inspecting the smallest singular value of the estimated Jacobian matrix $\mathcal{J}\left(\zeta_{T}\right)$. Specifically, we computed bootstrap confidence intervals for the smallest singular value, emphasizing that this process does not involve rigorous statistical inference. Now, we investigate whether such diagnostic checks are empirically plausible via Monte Carlo simulations.

We begin by considering the case where the change in VAR covariance matrices is sufficiently large to identify the model, consistent with the DGP considered thus far. Table S. 1 summarizes the average estimated smallest singular value of the Jacobian matrix across Monte Carlo simulations, along with the associated interquartile ranges (IQRs). IQRs are used here as broad approximations of confidence intervals. We explore scenarios with both relevant and local-to-zero instruments, as well as both exogenous and contaminated instruments. The results in Table S.1 indicate that when the change in volatility is sufficiently strong for identification, the smallest singular values of the estimated Jacobian matrix are far from zero, and the associated IQRs do not include zero. Furthermore, Table S. 1 shows that instrument properties do not affect the identifiability of the model, confirming the analytical results discussed in the paper and the results in Tables 1 and 2.

Our analysis proceeds by reexamining the performance of the stability restrictions approach under a different framework. In particular, to envisage how identification infor-

mation stemming from the change in unconditional volatility may deteriorate and lead to identification failure, we notice that setting $\Psi:=I_{n+r}$ (to simplify), the moment conditions (16) imply that the shift in volatility is entirely due to the nonzero elements in the matrix $\Delta_{G}$ :

$$
\Sigma_{\eta, 2}-\Sigma_{\eta, 1}=G \Delta_{G}^{\prime}+\Delta_{G} G^{\prime}+\Delta_{G} \Delta_{G}^{\prime}
$$

Recall that in (S.11), the nonzero entries in $\Delta_{G}(\delta)$ capture changes in the parameters in the transition from the first to the second volatility regime. This raises the question of how large the magnitude of shifts in $\Delta_{G}(\delta)$ must be in (S.11) for the approach outlined in the previous sections to remain valid. To characterize the phenomenon of "shrinking covariance shift", we relax Assumption 1(iv) (while keeping all the other assumptions valid) and approximate $\Delta_{G}$ in (S.11) by the local-to-zero condition:

$$
\Delta_{G}=\varrho_{T} \tilde{\Delta}_{G}
$$

where $\varrho_{T}$ is a scalar that converges to zero as the sample size increases, and $\tilde{\Delta}_{G}$ represents a re-scaled version of the matrix $\Delta_{G}$ that therefore fulfills the same stability restrictions as $\Delta_{G}$ in (18). According to (S.12), the magnitude of the change in volatility in the proxySVAR is controlled by the parameter $\varrho_{T} \rightarrow 0$, whose speed of convergence to zero plays a crucial role. Under (S.12), the distance between $\Sigma_{\eta, 2}$ and $\Sigma_{\eta, 1}$ in (S.11) can be written as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma_{\eta, 2}-\Sigma_{\eta, 1}= & \varrho_{T} G \tilde{\Delta}_{G}^{\prime}+\varrho_{T} \tilde{\Delta}_{G} G^{\prime}+\varrho_{T} \tilde{\Delta}_{G} \varrho_{T} \tilde{\Delta}_{G}^{\prime} \\
& =\varrho_{T} \underbrace{G \tilde{\Delta}_{G}^{\prime}+\tilde{\Delta}_{G} G^{\prime}+\tilde{\Delta}_{G} \varrho_{T} \tilde{\Delta}_{G}^{\prime}}_{C_{T}}
\end{aligned}
$$

so that it is seen that, as in Bai (2000), $C_{T} \rightarrow C=\left(G \tilde{\Delta}_{G}^{\prime}+\tilde{\Delta}_{G} G^{\prime}\right) \neq 0_{(n+r) \times(n+r)}$ and $\left(\Sigma_{\eta, 2}-\Sigma_{\eta, 1}\right) \rightarrow 0_{(n+r) \times(n+r)}$, as $\varrho_{T} \rightarrow 0$. Intuitively, given (S.13) and $T$ being large, the moment conditions in system (16) no longer produce $(n+r)(n+r+1)$ independent moment conditions that offer meaningful information on the parameters $\varsigma$. This could lead to the failure of the necessary and sufficient rank conditions for identification derived in Proposition 2.

By combining the conditions $\varrho_{T} \rightarrow 0$ with the stability restrictions (18), the implied Jacobian matrix now is:

$$
\tilde{\mathcal{J}}(\varsigma):=2\left(I_{2} \otimes D_{n+r}^{+}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\left(G \otimes I_{n+r}\right) & 0_{(n+r)^{2} \times(n+r)^{2}} \\
\left(G+\tilde{\Delta}_{G}\right) \otimes I_{n+r} & \left(G+\tilde{\Delta}_{G}\right) \otimes I_{n+r}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
S_{G} & 0 \\
0 & \varrho_{T} S_{\Delta_{G}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and demonstrates that, even in cases where $\tilde{\mathcal{J}}(\varsigma)$ has full column rank for nonzero values of $\varrho_{T}$ (no shrinking), identification fails as $\varrho_{T}$ approaches zero.

Table S. 2 summarizes the estimated smallest singular values of the Jacobian matrix and associated IQRs when VAR covariance matrices satisfy the conditions $\left(\Sigma_{\eta, 2}-\Sigma_{\eta, 1}\right) \rightarrow$ $0_{(n+r) \times(n+r)}$, as $\varrho_{T} \rightarrow 0$ and shrink at the rate $\varrho_{T} \sim o\left(T^{-1 / 2}\right)$. It can be observed a departure from the patterns seen in Table S.1. In contrast to the scenarios presented in Table S.1, where the ratio between the estimated average smallest singular value and the average length of the IQRs consistently exceeds 2, we now observe a distinct trend. Specifically, when exogeneity is not imposed in the estimation, this ratio is systematically less than 2 ,

regardless of instrument strength, indicating rank collapse of the Jacobian matrix $\mathcal{J}(\varsigma)$. Conversely, when instrument exogeneity is imposed in the estimation (regardless of its validity in the DGP), we do not observe rank collapse. This phenomenon arises because, when deviations from exogeneity are allowed, the instruments carry limited information about the non-target shocks under shrinking volatility shifts. Consequently, the limited identification information from the shifts in volatility extends to the entire system. In contrast, imposing instrument exogeneity prevents this information leakage. In this case, the only source of identification for the non-target shocks is the strong instruments.

We can argue that the results outlined in Tables S. 1 and S. 2 indirectly lend support to the indirect check of identifiability of the fiscal proxy-SVAR estimated in Section 3 of the paper.

# S. 6 FURTHER EMPIRICAL RESULTS 

In this section, we complement the empirical analyses presented in the paper with additional results. We define the fiscal multipliers used in the paper and discuss the specification of the benchmark proxy-SVAR estimated ignoring the break in volatility. Subsequently, we extend information about estimation and the dynamic tax multipliers. Finally, we discuss the estimated fiscal spending multipliers.

Fiscal multipliers Let $P_{t}$ represent either the level of fiscal spending or the level of tax revenues (not in logs), and $G D P_{t}^{e}$ denote the unlogged level of output. For simplicity, we use $\beta_{y_{h}}$ to denote the response of log-output at horizon $h$ to a one-standard deviation fiscal policy shock, and $\beta_{p_{0}}$ for the on-impact response of the logged fiscal variable to the corresponding one-standard deviation fiscal policy shock. Then, in our context, dynamic multipliers, defined as the dollar response of output to an effective change in the fiscal variable of 1 dollar occurred $h$ period before, are given by:

$$
\mathcal{M}_{p, h}:=\left(\beta_{y_{h}} / \beta_{p_{0}}\right) \times \text { Scaling }_{p}
$$

where Scaling $_{p}$ is a policy shock-specific scaling factor converting elasticities to dollars. We set the scaling factor equal to the sample means of the series $\left(G D P_{t}^{e} / P_{t}\right)$ computed over the estimation period. Thus, when in the paper we deal with the volatility change and the stability restriction approach, the scaling factor is calculated considering observations in the corresponding volatility regimes. We refer to Caldara and Kamps (2017) and Angelini, Caggiano, Castelnuovo, and Fanelli (2023) for a detailed discussion.

Specification with no shift in volatility The proxy-SVAR is estimated over the whole sample period 1950:Q1-2006:Q4, under the assumption that the fiscal instruments $z_{t}$ are relevant and exogenous for the target fiscal shocks $\varepsilon_{1, t}:=\left(\varepsilon_{t}^{\text {tax }}, \varepsilon_{t}^{g}\right)^{\prime}$. We consider the following specification:

$$
\binom{u_{t}^{\text {tax }}}{u_{t}^{g}}=\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{cc}
h_{1,1} & h_{1,2} \\
h_{2,1} & h_{2,2} \\
h_{3,1} & h_{3,2}
\end{array}\right)}_{H_{\bullet 1}} \underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{c}
\varepsilon_{t}^{\text {tax }} \\
\varepsilon_{t}^{g} \\
\varepsilon_{1, t}
\end{array}\right)}_{z_{1, t}}+H_{\bullet 2} \underbrace{\varepsilon_{t}^{\text {gdp }}}_{\varepsilon_{2, t}}
$$

$$
\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{c}
z_{t}^{\text {tax }} \\
z_{t}^{g} \\
z_{t}
\end{array}\right)}_{\xi_{t}}=\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\varphi_{1,1} & \varphi_{1,2} \\
0 & \varphi_{2,2}
\end{array}\right)}_{\Phi} \underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{c}
\varepsilon_{t}^{\text {tax }} \\
\varepsilon_{t}^{g} \\
\varepsilon_{t, t}
\end{array}\right)}_{\xi_{t}}+\underbrace{\left(\begin{array}{c}
\tilde{\zeta}_{t}^{\text {tax }} \\
\tilde{\zeta}_{t}^{g} \\
\tilde{\zeta}_{t}
\end{array}\right)}_{\tilde{\zeta}_{t}}
$$

where the zero restriction in the $(2,1)$ element of $\Phi$ is sufficient for identification (Angelini and Fanelli, 2019). The zero in the $(2,1)$ position of the matrix $\Phi$ in (S.16) posits that the fiscal spending proxy solely instruments the fiscal spending shock. In turn, we permit the tax proxy to possibly convey information on the fiscal spending shock other than the tax shock, allowing the data to inform on the significance of the parameter $\varphi_{1,2}$. Then we estimate the model by the CMD approach. In (S.15)-(S.16), $\tilde{\zeta}_{t}:=\left(\tilde{\zeta}_{t}^{\text {tax }}, \tilde{\zeta}_{t}^{g}\right)^{\prime}$ denotes the vector of (unnormalized) measurement errors associated with the two fiscal proxies.

Additional Descriptives In Section 3 we estimate a VAR for $Y_{t}:=\left(T R_{t}, G S_{t}, G D P_{t}\right)^{\prime}$ and two proxies $z_{t}:=\left(z_{t}^{\text {tax }}, z_{t}^{g}\right)^{\prime}$. The VAR residuals $\hat{u}_{t}=\left(\hat{u}_{t}^{\text {tax }}, \hat{u}_{t}^{g}, \hat{u}_{t}^{g d p}\right)^{\prime}, t=1, \ldots, T$ and the two fiscal proxies $z_{t}, t=1, \ldots, T$ are plotted over the sample period 1950:Q1-2006:Q4 in the left and right columns of Figure S.1, respectively. Standard residual-based diagnostic tests (available upon request), indicate that the VAR disturbances are serially uncorrelated but exhibit conditional heteroskedasticity. The graphs of the VAR residuals clearly show a reduction in variability beginning in the early 1980s. The estimated break point (Bai, 2000) corresponds to the vertical lines in Figure S.1.

Estimation. The proxy-SVAR specified in (24) involves $(a+b)=27$ parameters (those in the matrices $G$ and $\Delta_{G}$ in (24)), collected in the vector $\varsigma$, and is based on $(n+r)(n+r+$ $1)=30$ moment conditions provided by the VAR error covariance matrices $\Sigma_{\eta, 2}$ and $\Sigma_{\eta, 1}$, respectively. The model is overidentified if the necessary and sufficient rank condition in Proposition 2 holds. The parameters $\zeta_{T}$ estimated by the CMD approach are summarized in the upper panel of Table S.3, along with associated $68 \%$ MBB confidence intervals. The overidentifying restrictions test, reported at the bottom panel of Table S.3, strongly supports the estimated model with a p-value of 0.86 .

The CMD estimates in Table S. 3 reveal important information about the properties and quality of the instruments used to estimate fiscal proxy-SVAR. The tax instrument $z_{t}^{\text {tax }}$ is poorly correlated with the tax shock $\varepsilon_{t}^{\text {tax }}$ in the Great Inflation period, where the relevance parameter $\varphi_{1,1}$ is not statistically significant. However, the relevance of the tax instrument increases markedly in the Great Moderation regime, where the change parameter $\Delta_{\varphi_{1,1}}$, is significant and the overall magnitude and statistical significance of $\varphi_{1,1}+\Delta_{\varphi_{1,1}}$ become substantial. To illustrate, examining columns (ii) and (iii) of Table 3 in the text, we observe that the correlation between the tax proxy $z_{t}^{\text {tax }}$ and the estimated tax shock $\varepsilon_{t}^{\text {tax }}$ jumps from $15 \%$ to $45 \% .^{2}$ Moreover, the $68 \%$ MBB confidence interval for the contamination parameter, $v_{t a x}^{g}$, suggests that the tax proxy is negatively linked, albeit not dramatically, with the output shock. A similar finding is also documented in Keweloh, Klein, and Prüser (2024), leveraging the non-normality of structural shocks in a Bayesian approach; see also

CHECKs OF IDENTIFICATION. The smallest singular value of the estimated Jacobian matrix, $\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)$, shown at the bottom of Table S. 3 with associated $68 \%$ MBB confidence interval, provides an informal check of the quality of the identification. While we note that the bootstrap confidence interval for the smallest singular value does not include zero, we acknowledge that this cannot be considered conclusive statistical evidence that the rank condition in Proposition 2 is satisfied. Nonetheless, we find no clear indication of identification failure due to insufficient information from the detected volatility shift.

Additional Information about the Dynamic Tax Multipliers. The dynamic tax multipliers displayed in the upper panel of Figure 1 in the text display noticeable differences across the two volatility regimes. Relative to the case in which the proxy-SVAR is estimated on the entire sample ignoring the break in volatility (black solid line), we observe a significant reduction in magnitude in both volatility regimes, accompanied by a substantial reduction of estimation uncertainty.

Our estimate of the tax multiplier in column (ii) of Table 3, $\mathcal{M}_{\text {tax }}^{\text {peak }}$, peaks at 1.73 (8 quarters after the shock) during the Great Inflation and declines to a peak of 0.53 (onimpact) during the Great Moderation. However, while estimates for the Great Inflation where the tax narrative proxy weakly correlates with the tax shock are relatively precise, those for the Great Moderation, with a stronger correlation, are highly imprecise. on the Great Moderation, also the estimated output elasticity of tax revenues $\vartheta_{y}^{\text {tax }}$ displays a wide $68 \%$ MBB confidence interval. These results suggest two considerations. First, the peak tax multipliers obtained with the proxy-SVAR approach on the whole estimation sample (approximately 3 in Mertens and Ravn (2014) and 2.6 in our framework) may likely reflect a bias induced by not account for the shift in volatility, the change in the strength of the tax proxy across the volatility regimes and the possible, albeit modest, contamination of the tax proxy from the output shock. Second, accounting for the volatility shifts guarantees consistency of the estimates and reveals that the effect of exogenous tax shocks on output is considerably different across the two regimes considered.

Simple calculations show that the weighted average of our peak tax multipliers in the two macroeconomic regimes, using the fractions of sample observations before and after the volatility shift as weights, is approximately 1 . This value is close to the peak multiplier for tax cuts of 0.86 inferred by Lewis (2021) using his identification approach based on timevarying volatility and constant IRFs, a hypothesis that our estimates call into question.

Our estimated proxy-SVAR clearly indicates that tax cuts are less effective in stimulating output during the Great Moderation compared to the Great Inflation. This finding can be explained by considering the differences in price and wage flexibility and access to credit markets in these two periods. During the Great Inflation, when prices and wages were stickier, tax cuts had stronger real effects because nominal rigidities prevented rapid price adjustments that would have otherwise offset their impact. In contrast, during the Great Moderation, more flexible prices and wages allowed the economy to adjust more quickly through price changes, partially mitigating the real impact of tax cuts. Furthermore, during the Great Inflation, when households had limited access to credit markets, tax cuts provided a vital source of immediate liquidity, leading households to spend a larger

portion of their tax savings promptly, amplifying the impact on aggregate demand and output. Conversely, during the Great Moderation, with more developed financial markets and better access to credit, households could already smooth their consumption patterns through borrowing, making the effects of tax cuts less effective.

Fiscal spending multipliers As mentioned in the paper, our instrument $z_{t}^{g}$ for fiscal spending shock is borrowed from Angelini, Caggiano, et al. (2023). This proxy is constructed by "purging" the residuals obtained from a regression of a measure of news spending shocks proposed by Ramey (2011) on a set of macroeconomic indicators. The logic behind this construction is to remove the component of the one-step-ahead fiscal spending forecast error that can be anticipated based on narrative records. Hence, the time series $z_{t}^{g}$ does not coincide precisely with that used in Mertens and Ravn (2014) for instrumenting fiscal spending shocks. This explains why our results, obtained on the estimation sample from 1950:Q1-2006:Q4 without taking volatility change into account, do not match precisely those in Mertens and Ravn (2014).

The lower panel of Figure 1 displays the dynamic fiscal spending multipliers estimated from the proxy-SVAR. Solid red lines represent the Great Inflation period, with $68 \%$ MBB confidence intervals indicated by the red shaded areas. Solid blue lines represent the Great Moderation period, with $68 \%$ MBB confidence intervals indicated by the blue shaded areas. While the dynamic tax multipliers (shown in the top panel) exhibit pronounced differences in magnitude and uncertainty across the two periods, this is not the case for the dynamic fiscal spending multipliers.

The estimated peak fiscal spending multiplier, $\mathcal{M}_{g}^{\text {peak }}$, summarized in columns (ii) and (iii) of Table 3 is 2.40 in the Great Inflation regime and declines to 2.03 in the Great Moderation regime. These point estimates have comparable $68 \%$ MBB confidence intervals of $(1.2,2.5)$ and $(1.3,2.7)$, respectively. The only notable difference between the two volatility regimes is that the peak effect is achieved four quarters after the shock in the Great Inflation regime and two quarters after the shock in the Great Moderation regime. We observe that ignoring the volatility shift, see column (i) of Table 3, our estimate of the peak fiscal spending multiplier is comparable with the results in Caldara and Kamps (2017) obtained by estimating fiscal reaction functions and instrumenting non-fiscal shocks with non-fiscal instruments.

Interestingly, our findings on the fiscal spending multiplier diverge from those in Lewis (2021) while sharing both similarities and differences with Fritsche, Klein, and Rieth (2021). Lewis (2021), who considers the same estimation sample and a time-varying volatility approach with constant IRFs, detects a fiscal spending multiplier that peaks at 0.75 after two quarters but is estimated very imprecisely. In contrast, Fritsche et al. (2021) employ in one of their specifications Markov-switching dynamics across high- and low-volatility states, allowing IRFs to change across these states. Using an estimation sample that partially covers the period after the Global Financial Crisis, they find changes in the impact of government spending shocks between high- and low-volatility regimes, with the highvolatility state essentially matching our Great Inflation period and the low-volatility state covering our Great Moderation sample. Therefore, the main difference between their and our results can be attributed to our inclusion of the instrument $z_{t}^{g}$ and the simultaneous identification of the tax shock. Results on estimated relevance and contamination in Table 3 suggest that $z_{t}^{g}$ is a valid instrument. Fritsche et al. (2021) establish that the fiscal

spending multiplier is significantly higher in the low-volatility state (where it peaks around $2.5-3$ ) compared to the high-volatility state (where it peaks around 1.72-2). Our results are only partially consistent with these findings. While the magnitudes of our estimated fiscal spending multipliers are broadly comparable, we detect a larger multiplier during the Great Inflation (high-volatility state) relative to the Great Moderation (low-volatility state).

# S. 7 Proofs OF PROPOSITIONS 

Proof of Proposition 1: (i) Consider the sums:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{\Sigma}_{u, z}:=\frac{1}{T} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}=\frac{1}{T}\left\{\sum_{t=1}^{T_{B}} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}+\sum_{t=T_{B}+1}^{T} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right\} \\
& =\frac{1}{T}\left\{\frac{T_{B}}{T_{B}} \sum_{t=1}^{T_{B}} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}+\frac{T-T_{B}}{T-T_{B}} \sum_{t=T_{B}+1}^{T} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right\} \\
& =\frac{T_{B}}{T}\left\{\frac{1}{T_{B}} \sum_{t=1}^{T_{B}} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right\}+\frac{T-T_{B}}{T}\left\{\frac{1}{T-T_{B}} \sum_{t=T_{B}+1}^{T} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

For $T \rightarrow \infty$, using Assumptions and instrument relevance and exogeneity:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{T_{B}}{T}\left\{\frac{1}{T_{B}} \sum_{t=1}^{T_{B}} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right\} \xrightarrow{\mathbb{P}} \tau_{B}^{(0)} \mathbb{E}\left[u_{t} z_{t}^{\prime} \mathbb{I}\left(t \leq T_{B}\right)\right]:=\tau_{B}^{(0)}\binom{\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1, t} z_{t}^{\prime} \mathbb{I}\left(t \leq T_{B}\right)\right]}{\mathbb{E}\left[u_{2, t} z_{t}^{\prime} \mathbb{I}\left(t \leq T_{B}\right)\right]} \\
& =\tau_{B}^{(0)} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\{H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)} \varepsilon_{1, t}+H_{\bullet 2}^{(0)} \varepsilon_{2, t}\right\} z_{t}^{\prime}\right]=\tau_{B}^{(0)} H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)} \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{1, t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right]=\tau_{B}^{(0)} H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\left(\Phi^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}
\end{aligned}
$$

furthermore,

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{T-T_{B}}{T}\left\{\frac{1}{T-T_{B}} \sum_{t=T_{B}+1}^{T} \hat{u}_{t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right\} \xrightarrow{\mathbb{P}}\left(1-\tau_{B}^{(0)}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[u_{t} z_{t}^{\prime} \mathbb{I}\left(t>T_{B}\right)\right] \\
=\left(1-\tau_{B}^{(0)}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\left\{\left(H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}+\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}^{(0)}\right)\left(\Lambda_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\right)^{1 / 2} \varepsilon_{1, t}+\left(H_{\bullet 2}^{(0)}+\Delta_{H_{\bullet 2}}^{(0)}\right)\left(\Lambda_{\bullet 2}^{(0)}\right)^{1 / 2} \varepsilon_{2, t}\right\} z_{t}^{\prime}\right] \\
=\left(1-\tau_{B}^{(0)}\right)\left(H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}+\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}^{(0)}\right)\left(\Lambda_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\right)^{1 / 2} \mathbb{E}\left[\varepsilon_{1, t} z_{t}^{\prime}\right]=\left(1-\tau_{B}^{(0)}\right)\left(H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}+\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}^{(0)}\right)\left(\Lambda_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\Phi^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}
\end{gathered}
$$

where use has been made of the following matrix decompositions: $H^{(0)}=\left(H_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}, H_{\bullet 2}^{(0)}\right)$, $\Delta_{H}^{(0)}=\left(\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}^{(0)}, \Delta_{H_{\bullet 2}}^{(0)}\right)$,

$$
\Lambda^{(0)}=\left(\begin{array}{ll}
\Lambda_{\bullet 1}^{(0)} & \\
& \Lambda_{\bullet 2}^{(0)}
\end{array}\right)
$$

Considering (S.18) and (S.19) jointly, the result follows.
(ii) Estending the agument in (S.17) to the components $\hat{\Sigma}_{u_{2}, z}$ and $\hat{\Sigma}_{u_{1}, z}$ of $\hat{\Sigma}_{u, z}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{T_{B}}{T}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\frac{1}{T_{B}} \sum_{t=1}^{T_{B}} \hat{u}_{1, t} z_{t}^{\prime} \\
\frac{1}{T_{B}} \sum_{t=1}^{T_{B}} \hat{u}_{2, t} z_{t}^{\prime}
\end{array}\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} \tau_{B}^{(0)}\left(\begin{array}{l}
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1, t} z_{t}^{\prime \sharp}\left(t \leq T_{B}\right)\right] \\
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{2, t} z_{t}^{\prime \sharp}\left(t \leq T_{B}\right)\right]
\end{array}\right)=\tau_{B}^{(0)}\binom{H_{1,1}^{(0)}\left(\Phi^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}}{H_{2,1}^{(0)}\left(\Phi^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}} \\
& \frac{T-T_{B}}{T}\left(\begin{array}{ll}

\frac{1}{T-T_{B}} \sum_{t=T_{B}+1}^{T} \hat{u}_{2, t} z_{t}^{\prime}
\end{array}\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}}\left(1-\tau_{B}^{(0)}\right)\binom{\mathbb{E}\left[u_{1, t} z_{t}^{\prime \sharp}\left(t>T_{B}\right)\right]}{\mathbb{E}\left[u_{2, t} z_{t}^{\prime \sharp}\left(t>T_{B}\right)\right]}\right) \\
& \quad=\left(1-\tau_{B}^{(0)}\right)\binom{\left(H_{1,1}^{(0)}+\Delta_{H_{1,1}}^{(0)}\right)\left(\Lambda_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\Phi^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}}{\left(H_{2,1}^{(0)}+\Delta_{H_{2,1}}^{(0)}\right)\left(\Lambda_{\bullet 1}^{(0)}\right)^{1 / 2}\left(\Phi^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

It turns out that:

$$

$$

Proof of Corollary 1: The proof trivially follows from the proof of Proposition 1 by setting $\Delta_{H_{\bullet 1}}^{(0)}=0_{n \times k}$.
Proof of Proposition 2: (i) The result follows by deriving the moment conditions (16) with respect to the parameter $\varsigma:=\left(\gamma^{\prime}, \delta^{\prime}, \psi^{\prime}\right)^{\prime}$, applying standard matrix derivative rules;
(ii) the necessary order condition follows from the dimensions of the Jacobian matrix in (20).

Proof of Proposition 3: Let $\hat{Q}_{T}(\varsigma):=m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)^{\prime} \hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)$ be the objective function upon which CMD estimation is computed in (23). We observe that: (a) under the conditions of Proposition 2, $Q_{0}(\varsigma):=m\left(\sigma^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)^{\prime} V_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} m\left(\sigma^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)$ is uniquely maximized at $\varsigma^{(0)}$ in the neighborhood $\mathcal{N}_{\varsigma^{(0)}}$; (b) $\mathcal{P}_{\varsigma}$ is compact and $\mathcal{N}_{\varsigma^{(0)}} \subseteq \mathcal{P}_{\varsigma}$; (c) $Q_{0}(\varsigma)$ is continuous; (d) $\hat{Q}_{T}(\varsigma)$ converges uniformly in probability to $Q_{0}(\varsigma)$. To prove that (d) holds, recall that under Assumptions 1-2 $\hat{\sigma}_{\eta} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} \sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}$, and $m_{T}(\bullet, \varsigma)$ is continuous, hence $m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)$ by the Continuous Mapping Theorem. Also recall that it exists an estimator of the asymptotic covariance matrix $V_{\sigma_{\eta}}$ such that $\hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} V_{\sigma_{\eta}}$, see (23). Then, with $\|\cdot\|$ denoting the Euclidean norm, by the triangle and the Cauchy-Schwartz inequalities:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\hat{Q}_{T}(\varsigma)-Q_{0}(\varsigma)\right| \leq\left|\left[m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)-m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right]^{\prime} \hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}\left[m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)-m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right]\right| \\
& +\left|m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)^{\prime}\left[\hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}+\hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1 \eta}\right]\left[m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)-m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right]\right| \\
& +\left|m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)^{\prime}\left[\hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}-V_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}\right] m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right| \\
& \leq\left\|m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)-m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right\|^{2}\left\|\hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}\right\| \\
& +2\left\|m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right\|\left\|m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)-m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right\|\left\|\hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}\right\|
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
+\left\|m\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma\right)\right\|^{2}\left\|\hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}-V_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}\right\|
$$

so that $\sup _{\varsigma \in \mathcal{P}_{\varsigma}}\left|\hat{Q}_{T}(\varsigma)-Q_{0}(\varsigma)\right| \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} 0$. Given (a), (b), (c), and (d), the consistency result follows from Theorem 2.1 in Newey and McFadden (1994).

To prove asymptotic normality, we start from the first-order conditions implied by the problem (23) in the paper:

$$
\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)^{\prime} \hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)=0
$$

where $\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)$ denotes the Jacobian matrix $\mathcal{J}(\varsigma)=\mathcal{J}\left(\sigma_{\eta}, \varsigma\right):=\frac{\partial m\left(\sigma_{\eta}, \varsigma\right)}{\partial \varsigma^{\prime}}$ evaluated at the estimated parameters $\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}$, and $\hat{\varsigma}_{T}$ ). By expanding $m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)$ around $\varsigma^{(0)}$ and solving, yields the expression (valid in $\mathcal{N}_{\varsigma^{(0)}}$ ):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt{T}\left(\hat{\varsigma}_{T}-\varsigma^{(0)}\right) \\
& =-\left\{\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)^{\prime} \hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} \mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \bar{\varsigma}\right)\right\}^{-1} \mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)^{\prime} \hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} \sqrt{T} m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma^{(0)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\bar{\varsigma}$ is a mean value. From (23) and the delta-method:

$$
\sqrt{T} m_{T}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma^{(0)}\right) \xrightarrow{d} N\left(0, \mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right) V_{\sigma_{\eta}} \mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)^{\prime}\right)
$$

where $\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \varsigma^{(0)}\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} \mathcal{J}\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma^{(0)}\right)=\mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)$. From the consistency result in (i), as $T \rightarrow \infty$, $\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} \mathcal{J}\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma^{(0)}\right):=\mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)$ and $\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \bar{\varsigma}\right) \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}} \mathcal{J}\left(\sigma_{\eta}^{(0)}, \varsigma^{(0)}\right):=\mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)$, respectively. Moreover, the matrix $\mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)^{\prime} V_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} \mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)$ is nonsingular in $\mathcal{N}_{\varsigma^{(0)}}$ because of Proposition 2. It turns out that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -\left\{\mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right)^{\prime} \hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} \mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \bar{\varsigma}\right)\right\}^{-1} \mathcal{J}\left(\hat{\sigma}_{\eta}, \hat{\varsigma}_{T}\right) \hat{V}_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} \\
& \xrightarrow{\mathrm{P}}-\left\{\mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)^{\prime} V_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1} \mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)\right\}^{-1} \mathcal{J}\left(\varsigma^{(0)}\right)^{\prime} V_{\sigma_{\eta}}^{-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

so that the conclusion follows from (S.22) and the Slutzky theorem.

Black solid lines refer to multipliers estimated on the whole sample 1950:Q12006:Q4, without accounting for a break in volatility. Red solid lines refer to multipliers estimated on the first volatility regime 1950:Q1-1983:Q2 (Great Inflation). Blue solid lines refer to multipliers estimated on the second volatility regime 1983:Q3-2006:Q4 (Great Moderation). Green lines refer to multipliers obtained from the proxy-SVAR-H approach (see Proposition 2.(iii)), i.e. accounting for a volatility shift while maintaining regimeinvariant IRFs.

abstract:
When in proxy-SVARs the covariance matrix of VAR disturbances is subject to
exogenous, permanent breaks that cause IRFs to change across volatility
regimes, even strong, exogenous external instruments yield inconsistent
estimates of the dynamic causal effects. However, if these volatility shifts
are properly incorporated into the analysis through (testable) "stability
restrictions", we demonstrate that the target IRFs are point-identified and can
be estimated consistently under a necessary and sufficient rank condition. If
the shifts in volatility are sufficiently informative, standard asymptotic
inference remains valid even with (i) local-to-zero covariance between the
proxies and the instrumented structural shocks, and (ii) potential failures of
instrument exogeneity. Intuitively, shifts in volatility act similarly to
strong instruments that are correlated with both the target and non-target
shocks. We illustrate the effectiveness of our approach by revisiting a seminal
fiscal proxy-SVAR for the US economy. We detect a sharp change in the size of
the tax multiplier when the narrative tax instrument is complemented with the
decline in unconditional volatility observed during the transition from the
Great Inflation to the Great Moderation. The narrative tax instrument
contributes to identify the tax shock in both regimes, despite our empirical
analysis raises concerns about its "statistical" validity.
